document.title: Holomorphic forms, the \debar-equation, and duality on a reduced complex space

creator.contact: Håkan Samuelsson Kalm, Department of Mathematical Sciences, Division of Mathematics, University of Gothenburg and Chalmers University of Technology, SE-412 96 Göteborg, Sweden

abstract.name: Abstract.
abstract.p: We study two natural notions of holomorphic forms on a reduced pure n-dimensional complex space X: sections of the sheaves ΩX∙ of germs of holomorphic forms on X⁢reg that have a holomorphic extension to some ambient complex manifold, and sections of the sheaves ωX∙ introduced by Barlet. We show that ΩXp and ωX-np are Serre dual to each other in a certain sense. We also provide explicit, intrinsic and semi-global Koppelman formulas for the \debar-equation on X and introduce fine sheaves AXp,q and BXp,q of (p,q)-currents on X, that are smooth on X⁢reg, such that (AXp,∙,\debar) is a resolution of ΩXp and, if ΩX-np is Cohen-Macaulay, (BXp,∙,\debar) is a resolution of ωXp.

document.acknowledgements: Author partially supported by the Swedish Research Council

para.p: In contrast to the situation on a complex manifold, on a (singular) complex space there are several different notions, serving different purposes, of holomorphic differential forms. For instance, the Grothendieck dualizing sheaf See below for more information. is the adequate notion of canonical sheaf when generalizing Serre duality to Cohen-Macaulay spaces. On the other hand, if one wants Kodaira-type vanishing results, then the Grauert-Riemenschneider canonical sheaf 1 should be used. In general these sheaves of holomorphic differential forms are not equal.

From an analytic point of view there are (at least) three, in general different, particularly natural notions of holomorphic differential forms on a reduced pure-dimensional complex space X. We will use the following terminology: The strongly holomorphic forms,1 considered, e.g., in [25], is a generalization of the strongly holomorphic functions (i.e., sections of the structure sheaf); the weakly holomorphic forms is a generalization of the weakly holomorphic functions and are those holomorphic forms on X⁢reg that extend to ~X, where →~XX is a resolution of singularities; the Barlet-Henkin-Passare holomorphic forms are the sections of Barlet’s sheaves ωX∙, [13], and can be analytically realized, [25], as the meromorphic forms on X that are \debar-closed considered as principal value currents on X.1 A strongly holomorphic form is always weakly holomorphic and a weakly holomorphic form is automatically Barlet-Henkin-Passare holomorphic, [25, Proposition 1], but in general neither implication can be reversed. The Grauert-Riemenschneider canonical sheaf mentioned above is the sheaf of germs of weakly holomorphic forms of top degree and the Grothendieck dualizing sheaf is the analogous sheaf of Barlet-Henkin-Passare holomorphic forms. We mention that weakly holomorphic forms were studied by Griffiths in [23] but apart from that we will in this paper only be concerned with strongly and Barlet-Henkin-Passare holomorphic forms and relations between these two notions. Barlet-Henkin-Passare holomorphic forms provide an ideal framework for questions about various traces, i.e., direct images under finite holomorphic maps. This is manifested in [13, Section 2] about the “propriété de la trace universelle” as well as in [25, Section 4] about variants of the Abel and inverse Abel theorems.

We also mention the reflexive differential forms, defined as the reflexive hull of exterior powers of the Kähler differentials, studied, e.g., in [21] and [22] in the setting of the minimal model program. On a normal complex space the reflexive differential forms and the Barlet-Henkin-Passare holomorphic forms are the same. This is probably well-known to experts but we supply an argument at the end of Section 4. On a quasi-projective variety with at worst log terminal singularities the reflexive differential forms are also the same as the weakly holomorphic forms; this is (implied by) the main result in [22].

Let X be a reduced complex space of pure dimension n. Each point in X has a neighborhood U that can be identified with an analytic subset of some domain D in some CN; ↪UD. By pulling back the holomorphic p-forms in D to U⁢reg one obtains a notion of holomorphic p-forms on U. This construction gives us the sheaf ΩXp, which turns out to be an intrinsic coherent OX-module; notice in particular that =ΩX0OX.We will actually define ΩpX in a different way in Section 3 and then show that this is what we get. The sections of ΩXp are the strongly holomorphic p-forms.

By the same construction one defines the sheaf EXp,q of smooth (p,q)-forms on X. We are interested in finding a Dolbeault-type resolution of ΩXp by a complex of fine sheaves, i.e., sheaves which are modules over EX0,0. However, as opposed to the case when X is smooth, (EXp,∙,\debar) is not a resolution of ΩpX in general, see, e.g., [8, Example 1.1]. In order to get a tractable resolution of ΩpX one is thus led to consider sheaves of certain currents on X. The (p,q)-currents on X is the topological dual of the space of smooth compactly supported (-np,-nq)-forms on X with a certain topology. More concretely, if :iX↪D⊂CN is an embedding and μ is a (p,q)-current on X, then :=ν⁢i*μ is a (+pκ,+qκ)-current in D, where κ is the codimension of X, and ν.=ξ0 for any test form ξ in D whose pullback to X⁢reg vanishes. Conversely, if ν is such a current in D then there is a current μ on X such that =ν⁢i*μ. A current μ on X is said to have the standard extension property (SEP) with respect to a subvariety ⊂ZX if →⁢χ(/|h|2ϵ)μμ as →ϵ0, where χ is a smooth regularization of the characteristic function of ⊂[1,∞)R,Throughout this paper χ will denote such a function. and h is a holomorphic tuple that does not vanish identically on any component of Z; if =ZX we simply say that μ has the SEP on X. In particular, two currents with the SEP on X are equal on X if and only if they are equal on X⁢reg. For a pivotal example of a current with the SEP on X, let φ be a meromorphic p-form on X (possibly with values in a holomorphic line bundle →LX). Then, by [27], φ defines in a canonical and robust way a principal value current on X (that takes values in L if φ does).We will often identify a meromorphic form with its corresponding principal value current. We can now formulate our first result.

para.p: Part (i) for =p0 and =MD′∞ is a classical result by Malgrange [28, Théorème 4] answering a question by Grauert; for <MD′∞ it is due to Spallek [35]. Part (ii) for =p0, =MD′∞, and X a reduced complete intersection was first proved by Henkin and Polyakov [26]. For =p0 Corollary 1.4 is also proved in [7]. We remark that Corollary 1.4 is explicit in the sense that ⁢Pφ (resp. ⁢Kφ) provides an explicit holomorphic extension of φ to D′ (resp. explicit solutions to =⁢\debaruφ on X′⁢reg).

The integral operators K and P can be applied to more general forms, for instance to any semi-meromorphic form, but one has to be a bit careful with the Koppelman formulas. This is reflected in Theorem 5.4 below where we give a residue criterion for a meromorphic p-form φ to be strongly holomorphic, and moreover, if the criterion is fulfilled then ⁢Pφ is a concrete holomorphic extension of φ to D′. For =p0 this criterion is due to Tsikh [36] in case X is a complete intersection and to Andersson [5] in general; for >p0 and X a complete intersection it is due to Henkin and Passare [25]. As a corollary to Theorem 5.4 we get the following geometric condition ensuring that any meromorphic p-form on X that is holomorphic on X⁢reg indeed is strongly holomorphic. We first recall the singularity subvarieties ⁢S0(F)⊂⁢S1(F)⊂⋯⊂X of a coherent analytic sheaf F on X; ⁢Sℓ(F) is the set of points ∈xX such that ≤⁢depthOX,x(Fx)ℓ, cf. [34, §1]. These sets are indeed analytic.

para.p: In case =p0 the conditions of Proposition 1.5 are (equivalent to) Serre’s conditions ⁢R1 and ⁢S2 for normality and thus, at least in this case the converse to Proposition 1.5 holds. Let us also notice that if the conditions are fulfilled for =pn and one a priori knows that X is locally a complete intersection, then it follows that X is smooth. To see this assume that X={f1=⋯=fκ=0}⊂D⊂CN has codimension κ, that ≠∧⁢df1⋯⁢dfκ0 on X⁢reg, and that the conditions of Proposition 1.5 are satisfied. Let ~ω be a meromorphic n-form in D such that the polar set of ~ω intersects X properly and such that, outside of the polar set of ~ω, =∧⁢df1⋯⁢dfκ~ω⁢dzWe will use the abbreviation ⁢dz for ∧⁢dz1⋯⁢dzN throughout this paper. for some local coordinates z in D. Let ω be the pullback of ~ω to X. Then ω is a holomorphic n-form on X⁢reg that is uniquely determined by ⁢dz and X; in fact, ω is the Poincaré-Leray residue of the meromorphic form /⁢dz(⁢f1⋯fκ). By Proposition 1.5, ω is strongly holomorphic and so, since =∧⁢df1⋯⁢dfκω⁢dz, it follows that ≠∧⁢df1⋯⁢dfκ0 on X.

The sheaf ωXp was introduced by Barlet in [13] in an algebraic way. However, we will use an alternative analytic description of ωXp as our definition; for us ωXp is the sheaf of germs of \debar-closed meromorphic (p,0)-currents on X. This analytic point of view is emphasized in [25] and we refer to ωXp as the sheaf of germs of Barlet-Henkin-Passare holomorphic p-forms. It is worth noticing that ωXp is torsion free, [13].

Recall that ωnX is the Grothendieck dualizing sheaf. A partial explanation for the terminology is that if X is Cohen-Macaulay and, e.g., compact then ⁢H-nq(X,ωXn) is the dual space of ⁢Hq(X,OX). It follows that if G is a locally free sheaf on X then ⁢H-nq(X,⁢Hom(G,ωXn)) is the dual of ⁢Hq(X,G) under the same assumptions on X. Pretending for the moment that ΩXp is locally free we would get a duality between ⁢Hq(X,ΩXp) and ⁢H-nq(X,⁢Hom(ΩXp,ωXn)). This last statement is actually true if X is Cohen-Macaulay and, e.g., compact. In fact, by Corollary 4.2 below we have that ≃⁢Hom(ΩXp,ωXn)ωX-np for a general X, and from Section 7 it follows that for any locally free sheaf F on X there is a non-degenerate pairing

para.p: We remark that Ramis and Ruget [30] have a quite general abstract duality result for any coherent sheaf on any complex space. The novelty with Theorem 1.8 is, apart from being a concrete realization of Serre duality in terms of Dolbeault cohomology analogous to the smooth case, that it connects two natural notions of holomorphic forms.

Notice that if X is compact then, by the Cartan-Serre theorem, the cohomology of coherent sheaves on X is finite dimensional, in particular Hausdorff. In the compact case the pairing of Theorem 1.8 is thus always non-degenerate. The pairing is also always non-degenerate if X is holomorphically convex since then, by [29, Lemma II.1], ⁢Hq(X,S) is Hausdorff for any coherent sheaf S. If X is k-convex it follows from the Andreotti-Grauert theorem that for any coherent sheaf S, ⁢Hq(X,S) is Hausdorff for ≥qk. Hence, in this case, the pairing is non-degenerate for ≥qk.

The paper is organized as follows. In Section 2 we recall some background material that we will use. In Section 3 we show that the sheaf ΩXp is coherent and we introduce the notion of an -np-structure form on X; this is a generalized Poincaré-Leray residue that will be crucial for what follows. In Section 4 we recall some properties of ωXp and show some other ones that we do not have found in the literature. In Section 5 we construct intrinsic integral operators for the \debar-equation on a pure n-dimensional analytic subset of a strictly pseudoconvex domain in CN; in Section 5.1 we also give the residue criterion for strong holomorphicity and we show a slightly more general result than Proposition 1.5. In Section 6 we define the sheaves AX∙,∙ and BX∙,∙ and prove Theorems 1.1It follows by combining Propositions 6.1 and 6.2., 1.3, 1.6, and 1.7. In Section 7 we show that ΩXp and ωX-np are Serre dual to each other in the sense of Theorem 1.8.

Let X be a pure-dimensional analytic subset of some domain ⊂DCN and let W be an analytic subset containing X⁢sing but not any component of X. It is proved in [25] that the following conditions on a holomorphic p-form φ on ∖XW are equivalent. 1) φ is locally the pullback to ∖XW of a meromorphic p-form in a neighborhood of X. 2) For any desingularization :π→~XX such that ≃⁢π-1X⁢regX⁢reg, ⁢π*φ has a meromorphic extension ~X. 3) There is a current T in D such that ⁢i*φ=T↾∖DW, where :i↪XD is the inclusion. 4) For any ∈h⁢O(X) that vanishes on W, but not identically on any component of X, the current

The sheaf of germs of p-forms satisfying these conditions is called the sheaf of germs of meromorphic p-forms on X; we will denote it by MpX. One can check that if ∈xX is an irreducible point then M0X,x is (isomorphic to) the field of fractions of OX,x. We mention again that we usually make no distinction between a meromorphic form φ and the associated principal value current (2.1).

Pseudomeromorphic currents were introduced in [10]; the definition we need and will use is from [8]. In one complex variable z it is elementary to see that the principal value current /1zm exists and can be defined, e.g., as the limit as →ϵ0 in the sense of currents of /⁢χ(/|⁢h(z)|2ϵ)zm, where h is a holomorphic function (or tuple) vanishing at =z0, or as the value at =λ0 of the analytic continuation of the current-valued function ↦λ/|⁢h(z)|⁢2λzm. It follows that the residue current ⁢\debar(/1zm) can be computed as the limit of /⁢\debarχ(/|⁢h(z)|2ϵ)zm or as the value at =λ0 of ↦λ/⁢\debar|⁢h(z)|⁢2λzm. The union of all germs of pseudomeromorphic currents on X forms an open subset of the sheaf of germs of currents on X and thus defines a subsheaf ⁢PMX. Notice that since \debar maps an elementary pseudomeromorphic current to a sum of such currents it follows that \debar maps ⁢PMX to itself.
The following result is fundamental and will be used repeatedly in this paper.

Another fundamental property of pseudomeromorphic currents is that they can be “restricted” to analytic (or constructible) subsets: Let ∈μ⁢PM(X), let ⊂VX be an analytic subset, and set :=Vc∖XV. Then the restriction of μ to the open subset Vc has a natural pseudomeromorphic extension ⁢1Vcμ to X. It follows that :=⁢1Vμ-μ⁢1Vcμ is a pseudomeromorphic current with support contained in V. In [10] ⁢1Vcμ is defined as the value at 0 of the analytic continuation of the current-valued function ↦λ⁢|h|⁢2λμ, where h is any holomorphic tuple with zero set V; ⁢1Vcμ can also be defined as lim→ϵ0⁢χ(/⁢|h|2vϵ)μ, where v is any smooth strictly positive function, see [11, Lemma 3.1], cf. also [32, Lemma 6].ϵ-approximations and λ-approximations can be used interchangeably; λ-approximations are often computationally easier to work with while we believe that ϵ-approximations are conceptually easier. On the other hand, if =∧lim→ϵ0⁢\debarχ(/|h|2ϵ)μ0 then, by (2.3), =⁢\debarμ⁢1∖XY\debarμ and so the “if” part of (ii) follows from Lemma 2.1. ∎

Recall that a current on X is said to be semi-meromorphic if it a principal value current of the form /αf, where α is a smooth form and f is a holomorphic function or section of a complex line bundle such that f does not vanish identically on any component of X. Following [8], see also [11], we say that a current a on X is almost semi-meromorphic if there is a modification :π→X′X and a semi-meromorphic current /αf on X′ such that =a⁢π*(/αf); if f takes values in →LX′ we need also α to take values in →LX′ if we want a to be scalar valued. If a is almost semi-meromorphic on X then the smallest Zariski-closed set outside of which a is smooth has positive codimension and is denoted ⁢ZSS(a), the Zariski-singular support of a, see [11].

For proofs of the statements in this paragraph we refer to [11, Section 3], see also [8, Section 2]. Let a be an almost semi-meromorphic current on X and let ∈μ⁢PM(X). Then there is a unique pseudomeromorphic current T on X coinciding with ∧aμ outside of ⁢ZSS(a) and such that =⁢1⁢ZSS(a)T0. If h is a holomorphic tuple, or section of a Hermitian vector bundle, such that {h=0}=ZSS(a), then =T∧lim→ϵ0⁢χ(/|h|2ϵ)aμ; henceforth we will write ∧aμ in place of T. One defines ∧⁢\debaraμ so that Leibniz’ rule holds, i.e., :=∧⁢\debaraμ∧-⁢\debar(∧aμ)⁢(-1)⁢degaa⁢\debarμ. If ∈μ⁢W(X) then ∈∧aμ⁢W(X); in this case =∧aμ∧lim→ϵ0⁢χ(/|h|2ϵ)aμ if h is any generically non-vanishing holomorphic section of a Hermitian vector bundle such that {h=0}⊃ZSS(a). If μ is almost semi-meromorphic then ∧aμ is almost semi-meromorphic and, in fact, =∧aμ∧⁢(-1)⁢degadegμμa.

Let X be an analytic subset of pure codimension κ of some complex N-dimensional manifold D. The subsheaves of ⁢PMD of germs of \debar-closed (k,κ)-currents, =k0,…,N, with support on X are the sheaves of Coleff-Herrera currents with support on X and are denoted ⁢CHXk. Coleff-Herrera currents were originally introduced by Björk as the \debar-closed currents μ on D of bidegree (N,κ) such that =⁢¯hμ0 for any holomorphic function h vanishing on X and with the SEP with respect to X, see, e.g., [14]. It is proved in [4] that the definitions are equivalent. The model example is the Coleff-Herrera product: Assume that ∈f1,…,fκ⁢O(D) defines a regular sequence. Then the iteratively defined product ∧⁢\debar(/1f1)⋯⁢\debar(/1fκ) is the Coleff-Herrera product originally introduced by Coleff and Herrera in [16] in a slightly different way; cf. also [15].

Let us also notice that if X and Z are reduced pure-dimensional complex spaces and ∈μ⁢PM(X), then ∈⊗μ1⁢PM(×XZ), see, e.g., [8, Section 2]. We will usually omit “⊗1” and simply write, e.g., ⁢μ(ζ) to denote which coordinates μ depends on.

At first sight this seems to contradict the discussion in Paragraph 2 of the Introduction. To shed some light on this notice first that ∧Rk⁢dz is a (distribution-valued) section of ⁢⊗EkE*0ΛN,kT*B and recall that =E0⁢Λp,0T*B. Therefore we can view ∧R⁢dz either as an (N,*)-current with values in ≃⁢Hom(E0,E)⊗EE0* or as an (-Np,*)-current with values in E; with the first viewpoint ∧R⁢dz acts naturally on ⊗E0E*-valued (0,*)-test forms and with the second it acts on E*-valued (p,*)-test forms and the result is the same. For future reference we also note that with the first point of view ∧R⁢dz can be naturally multiplied with smooth E0-valued (0,*)-forms yielding E-valued currents; with the second point of view ∧R⁢dz can be naturally multiplied with scalar-valued (p,*)-forms yielding the same E-valued currents. Unless explicitly said, we will use the second point of view (even though the notation might suggest otherwise).

para.p: Notice first that a holomorphic p-form in B has the property =∧φ[X]0 if and only if the pullback of φ to X⁢reg vanishes.

If φ is a section of JpX, then the pullback of φ to X⁢reg must vanish since =JpX~JpX generically on X⁢reg. On the other hand, if the pullback of φ to X⁢reg vanishes, then =∧ω⁢i*φ0 in the current sense on X since ω has the SEP. From Proposition 3.4 and the discussion preceding it, it follows that =⁢Rφ0, where we here view φ as a section of ⁢O(E0). Hence, φ is a section of JpX. ∎

The corollary shows that ΩXp indeed is the sheaf of holomorphic p-forms on X⁢reg that (locally) have a holomorphic extension to B. Since any two local embeddings of X in CN with N minimal are holomorphically equivalent, and any local embedding of X in CM factors through a minimal embedding via ↪CN×CNC-MN it follows that ΩXp is the sheaf defined in the introduction.

para.p: The sheaf ωpX was introduced by Barlet in [13] in an algebraic way. However, by [13, Proposition 4], ≃ωXp⁢/DXpH0X⁢sing(DXp), where DXp is the sheaf of \debar-closed (p,0)-currents on X and ⁢H0X⁢sing(DXp) is the subsheaf of DXp of germs of currents with support contained in X⁢sing. This subsheaf is in general nonzero but by [25, Theorem 1] each element in ⁢/DXpH0X⁢sing(DXp) has a (necessarily unique) representation as a meromorphic \debar-closed (p,0)-current on X. It follows that Barlet’s definition of ωpX is equivalent to the one we and Henkin-Passare use.

Notice that it follows that ωXp is coherent, which of course also is proved in [13]. That the vertical map in the proof of Proposition 4.1 is an isomorphism can be seen as a version of/complement to [13, Lemma 4]. In fact, in view of [6, Theorem 1.5], in our terminology that lemma says that ωXp, via i*, is isomorphic to the sheaf of germs of Coleff-Herrera currents μ in B of bidegree (+κp,κ) such that =⁢JX0μ0 and =∧⁢dJX0μ0, i.e., such that =μ⁢i*τ for some (p,0)-current τ on X; cf. the paragraph after the Dimension principle in Section 2.2. Let us give a related interpretation, corresponding to [13, Proposition 3], of the fact that the vertical map in the proof of Proposition 4.1 is an isomorphism.

para.p: Part (i) is immediate from Corollary 4.2. Part (ii) clearly holds on X⁢reg. Since ΩX-np has pure dimension and currents in ωXp have the SEP the non-degeneracy extends to X. To see part (iii) we recall first the well-known fact that if ΩX-np is Cohen-Macaulay (and ⁢O(E∙) is a minimal resolution of ΩX-np), then ⁢Hκ(⊗⁢O(E*∙)ΩN) is Cohen-Macaulay. The first claim of part (iii) thus follows from Proposition 4.1. For the second claim, recall that =ωω0 is \debar-closed since ΩX-np is Cohen-Macaulay. Thus, by Theorem 5.4 below, φ is in ΩX-np if and only if =⁢\debar(∧φω0)0. Now, ω0 is an ↾XEκ-valued section of ωXp, that is, a tuple of sections of ωXp, and we are done. ∎
Part (ii) is a concrete manifestation of [6, Theorem 1.2] for the sheaf =FΩX-np.
We conclude this section by showing that, on a normal complex space X, ωXp coincides with the reflexive hull of the pth exterior power of the sheaf of Kähler differentials, denoted ΩX[p] as in [22].

p.text: Let X be a germ of a reduced pure-dimensional complex space. Then the restriction map →⁢ωp(X)⁢ωp(∖XA) is bijective for any p and any analytic ⊂AX with ≥⁢codimXA2.

para.p: Since sections of ωXp have the SEP it is clear the restriction map is injective. For the surjectivity, assume that X is a pure n-dimensional analytic subset of a neighborhood of ∈0CN. From the local parametrization theorem we know that we for a generic choice of coordinates z on CN may assume that we are in the following situation, cf., e.g., [17, Chapter II, Proposition 6.1]. The restriction of the projection ↦(z1,…,zN)(z1,…,zn) to ∩XΔ, for some small polydisc ⊂ΔCN centered at 0, defines a ramified covering :π→∩XΔΔ′, where Δ′ is a suitable polydisc in Cn, such that ⁢codimΔ′π(A)=⁢codimXA≥2. Let ∈φ⁢ωp(∖XA) and let ψ be any strongly holomorphic form on X. Then, since =⁢\debar(∧φψ)0 in the sense of currents on ∖XA we get that =∧⁢\debarπ*φψ0 in the current sense on ∖Δ′⁢π(A). Thus, ∧⁢π*φψ is holomorphic on ∖Δ′⁢π(A). But Δ′ is smooth and ≥⁢codimΔ′π(A)2 and so ∧⁢π*φψ extends to a holomorphic form on Δ′. In view of [13, Section 2, Proposition 2], cf. also [25, Proposition 2], it follows that φ extends to an element in ⁢ωp(X). ∎
For injectivity of the restriction map it suffices that ≥⁢codimXA1.

para.p: It is clear that ωXp and ΩX[p] coincide on X⁢reg. Moreover, on a normal complex space a coherent sheaf F is reflexive if and only if it is torsion free and for each open ⊂UX and each closed analytic ⊂AU with ≥⁢codimXA2 the restriction map →⁢F(U)⁢F(∖UA) is bijective, see [24, Proposition 1.6]. In view of Proposition 4.5 and since ≥⁢codimXX⁢sing2 on a normal space, we have ⁢ωp(U)≃⁢ωp(U⁢reg)≃⁢Ω[p](U⁢reg)≃⁢Ω[p](U) for any open ⊂UX.

para.p: In view of Section 2.2, T is almost semi-meromorphic since each factor is. For the second statement we proceed by induction over ν. If =ν0 then =Tω. Since R is ∇End-closed it follows that ⁢\debarω=f↾Xω, which has the SEP. From Lemma 2.2 we see that →∧⁢\debarχ(/|h|2ϵ)ω0 as →ϵ0.

Now assume that ≥ν1 and assume that the lemma holds for ≤ν-ℓ1. Let T be given by (5.14) with =νℓ. If ≠zkz-k1 then kk is a smooth form times some -np-structure form ⁢~ω(z-k1). It follows that =T∧T′T′′ is the tensor product of two currents T′ and T′′ of the form (5.14) with <νℓ as long as ≠zkz-k1. By the induction hypothesis →∧⁢\debarχ(/|h|2ϵ)T0 where ≠zkz-k1. Thus we see that the support of the pseudomeromorphic current ∧lim→ϵ0⁢\debarχ(/|h|2ϵ)T must be contained in {z0=⋯=zν}∩{h=0}, which has codimension ≥+⁢nν1. Let Tr be the term of T corresponding to the term ωr of ω. Then the pseudomeromorphic current ∧lim→ϵ0⁢\debarχ(/|h|2ϵ)T0 has bidegree (-+⁢nνnp,-+⁢nν1ν) and thus must vanish by the Dimension principle. By Proposition 3.4 (ii) there is an almost semi-meromorphic (0,1)-current α1 that is smooth outside of Z+κ1 and such that =ω1⁢α1ω0. From what we have just showed it follows that the pseudomeromorphic (-+⁢nνnp,-+⁢nν2ν)-current ∧lim→ϵ0⁢\debarχ(/|h|2ϵ)T1 has support in {z0=⋯=zν}∩{h=0}∩{zj∈Z+κ1}, which has codimension ≥+⁢nν2. Hence that current vanishes by the Dimension principle. Continuing in this way the lemma follows. ∎

para.p: In order to construct the integral operators K we choose the weight g in the definitions of ⁢p(ζ,z) and ⁢k(ζ,z) to be a weight with respect to z∈D′⋐D such that ↦ζ⁢g(ζ,z) has compact support in D. Let φ be a pseudomeromorphic (p,q)-current on X. In view of Section 2.2, ∧⁢k(ζ,z)⁢φ(ζ) and ∧⁢p(ζ,z)⁢φ(ζ) are well-defined pseudomeromorphic currents in ×XζXz′, where =X′∩XD′. para.p: Since ↦ζ⁢g(ζ,z) has compact support in D it follows that ⁢Kφ and ⁢Pφ are well-defined pseudomeromorphic currents in X′. Notice that ⁢Pφ has a natural smooth extension to D′ since ↦z⁢p(ζ,z) has; notice also that if φ has the SEP then ⁢Kφ has the SEP in view of Section 2.2. Moreover, as in [8, Lemma 6.1] one shows that if =φ0 in a neighborhood of a point ∈xX′, or if φ is smooth in a neighborhood of x and ∈xX⁢reg′, then ⁢Kφ is smooth in a neighborhood of x.

If φ is a pseudomeromorphic (p,q)-current with compact support in X, then one can choose any weight g in the definitions of ⁢k(ζ,z) and ⁢p(ζ,z) and define ⁢Kφ and ⁢Pφ by (5.15); the outcome has the same general properties.
The following proposition is proved in the same way as [8, Proposition 6.3].

para.p: Notice that the condition that ⁢\debar(∧ωφ) has the SEP implies that ⁢\debarφ has the SEP. In fact, from Section 2.2 we know that ∧ωφ has the SEP and so, in view of Lemma 2.2, ⁢\debar(∧ωφ) has the SEP if and only if →∧⁢\debarχ(/|h|2ϵ)ωφ0 for all generically non-vanishing h. In particular, →∧⁢\debarχ(/|h|2ϵ)ω0φ0 and so, by Lemma 3.6, →∧⁢\debarχ(/|h|2ϵ)φ0. By Lemma 2.2 again we conclude that ⁢\debarφ has the SEP.
From Proposition 5.3 it is easy to prove the following residue criterion for a meromorphic p-form to be strongly holomorphic. Recall the operator =∇-⊕jfj\debar. attached to (2.6).

Then a meromorphic p-form φ on X is strongly holomorphic if and only if

For the converse, notice that ∧ωφ has the SEP so that →∧⁢χ(/|h|2ϵ)ωφ∧ωφ for all generically non-vanishing h. Hence, if (5.16) holds, we get

We have already seen one application of this result, namely Proposition 4.3. Let us try to shed some further light on the criterion. Assume for simplicity that =p0 and that =φ/gh, where h is generically non-vanishing on X. In view of Proposition 3.4, (5.16) is equivalent to =∇(⁢φR)0, which is Andersson’s formulation [5] of the criterion. Assume in addition that X={f1=⋯=fκ=0} is a reduced complete intersection. Then R is the Coleff-Herrera product ∧⁢\debar(/1f1)⋯⁢\debar(/1fκ) (times some frame element), cf. Example 2.4. In this case (5.16) is thus equivalent to

Math.text: g * [\debar] * (1 / h) and [\debar] * (1 / f _ 1) and cdots and [\debar] * (1 / f _ kappa) = 0

para.p: which holds if and only if g is in the ideal ⟨h,f1,…,fκ⟩, i.e., if and only if g is divisible by h on X. This is the philosophy of Tsikh’s result [36].
Instead of proving Proposition 1.5 we show the following more general result.

Since ω and φ are almost semi-meromorphic we have ∧±ωφ=∧φω=∧lim→ϵ0⁢χ(/|h|2ϵ)φω, where h is a generically non-vanishing holomorphic function such that {h=0}⊃Pφ. Thus, since =∇ω0, we see that =∇(∧ωφ)∧±lim→ϵ0⁢\debarχ(/|h|2ϵ)φω and so we need to show that

Recall from Section 2.3 the sets Zk associated with a resolution (2.6) of ΩpX and that =⁢S-Nk(ΩpX)Zk. Assumption (ii) is thus equivalent to ≥∩⁢codimZkPφ+k2 for ≥k+-Nn1. Now, assume that (5.17) holds for =ℓm. Thus, (5.17) holds for =ℓ+m1 by assumption (ii) and the Dimension principle. ∎

Then =∧φψ⁢\debar(∧~φψ) at least on X⁢reg. However, by Theorem 7.1, both the left and the right hand side has the SEP so this holds on X. Hence, (φ,ψ) is mapped to 0 by Stokes’ theorem.

Let ~X be an analytic subset of ⊂¯DCN, where D is pseudoconvex, and set :=X∩~XD. Let F be a holomorphic vector bundle on X and let F be the associated locally free OX-module. Since X is Stein and ⊗FΩXp is coherent it follows from Corollary 1.2 that the complex

Math.text: 0 to A ^ (list@(p, 0)) * open-interval@(X, F) longrightarrow ^ [\debar] A ^ (list@(p, 1)) * open-interval@(X, F) longrightarrow ^ [\debar] cdots longrightarrow ^ [\debar] A ^ (list@(p, n)) * open-interval@(X, F) to 0

para.p: is exact except for on the level 0 where the cohomology is ⁢Ωp(X,F). We endow ⁢Ωp(X,F) with the standard canonical Fréchet space topology, see, e.g., [17, Chapter IX].

p.text: Let ⁢Bc-np,q(X,F*) be the space of sections of ⊗F*BX-np,q with compact support in X. The complex

Math.text: 0 to (B _ c) ^ (list@(n - p, 0)) * open-interval@(X, F ^ *) longrightarrow ^ [\debar] (B _ c) ^ (list@(n - p, 1)) * open-interval@(X, F ^ *) longrightarrow ^ [\debar] cdots longrightarrow ^ [\debar] (B _ c) ^ (list@(n - p, n)) * open-interval@(X, F ^ *) to 0

p.text: is exact except for on the level n and the pairing

Math.text: formulae@(Omega ^ p * open-interval@(X, F) * H ^ n * open-interval@((B _ c) ^ (list@(n - p, bullet)) * open-interval@(X, F ^ *), []) to C, open-interval@(varphi, delimited-[]@(psi)) maps-to (integral _ X)@(varphi cdot psi))

para.p: Since we are in the local situation we may assume that an element in ⁢B-np,qc(X,F*) is just a tuple of elements in ⁢Bc-np,q(X) and carry out the following argument component-wise. Let ∈ψ⁢Bc-np,q(X) be \debar-closed. Let D′⋐D′′⊂D, where ⊂⁢suppψD′ and D′′ is strictly pseudoconvex, and construct ⁢k(ζ,z) and ⁢p(ζ,z) as in Section 5 with a weight ⁢g(ζ,z) with respect to ∈zD′ such that ↦z⁢g(ζ,z) is holomorphic in D′ and ↦ζ⁢g(ζ,z) has compact support in D′′. Then =⁢p(ζ,z)∧∑k⁢~p+κk(ζ,z)⁢ωk(ζ), where ↦ζ⁢~p+κk(ζ,z) has compact support in D′′ and ↦z⁢~p+κk(ζ,z) is a section of ΩpX over :=X′∩XD′.
As in the proof of Theorem 1.7 we get

Math.text: psi = [\debar] * check@(K) * psi + check@(P) * psi

para.p: in X′. From the properties of ⁢p(ζ,z) we get that =⁢ˇPψ0 if <qn so (7.1) is exact except for on the level n. If =qn then the cohomology class of ψ is represented by ⁢ˇPψ and

Math.text: check@(P) * psi = (plus-or-minus (sum _ (k >= 0))@(omega _ k * zeta)) and (integral _ X _ z)@((tilde@(p)) _ (kappa + k) * open-interval@(zeta, z)) and psi * z

para.p: Hence, if =∫X⁢φψ0 for all ∈φ⁢Ωp(X) then =⁢ˇPψ0 and the cohomology class of ψ thus is 0. It follows that ⁢Hn(⁢Bc-np,∙(X),\debar), via (7.2), is a subset of the topological dual of ⁢Ωp(X).

Let λ be a continuous linear functional on ⁢Ωp(X). Then λ induces a continuous functional ~λ on ⁢Ωp(D) that has to be carried by some compact ⋐KD. By the Hahn-Banach theorem there is an (-Np,N)-current μ of order 0 in D with support in a neighborhood ⋐⁢U(K)D of K such that =⁢~λ(~f)∧∫~fμ for all ∈~f⁢Ωp(D). Now choose a weight ⁢g(ζ,z) with respect to ∈z⁢U(K) that is holomorphic for ∈z⁢U(K) and has compact support in Dζ and let =⁢p(ζ,z)∧∑k⁢~p+κk(ζ,z)⁢ωk(ζ) be a corresponding integral kernel. We set

Math.text: check@(P) * mu assign (sum _ (k >= 0))@(omega _ k * zeta) and (integral _ D _ z)@((tilde@(p)) _ (kappa + k) * open-interval@(zeta, z)) and mu * z

para.p: and observe that ∈⁢ˇPμ⁢Bc-np,n(X). Let ∈φ⁢Ωp(X) and set :=~φ⁢Pφ. Then ∈~φ⁢Ωp(⁢U(K)) by the choice of weight and moreover, ~φ↾∩⁢U(K)X=φ↾∩⁢U(K)X. We get

Math.text: lambda * varphi = tilde@(lambda) * tilde@(varphi) = (integral _ D _ z)@(tilde@(varphi)) and mu = (integral _ D _ z)@(P * varphi) and mu = (integral _ X _ zeta)@(varphi) and check@(P) * mu

para.p: and so λ is given by integration against ∈⁢ˇPμ⁢Bc-np,n(X). For more details of the last part of the proof see the proof of [31, Theorem 6.1]. ∎

Let us briefly recall how one can patch up the local duality to the global one of Theorem 1.8; cf., e.g., [31, Section 6.2]. Let :=U{Uj} be a locally finite open covering of X such that each Uj can be identified with an analytic subset of some pseudoconvex domain in some CN. In view of Theorem 1.1 and Corollary 1.2 this gives us a Leray covering for ⊗FΩXp. Recall that spaces of sections of ⊗FΩXp has a standard Fréchet space structure. We let ⁢Ck(U,⊗FΩXp) be the group of formal sums

Math.text: list@((sum _ (i _ 0 * cdots * i _ k))@(varphi _ (i _ 0 * cdots * i _ k) * U _ i _ 0) and cdots and U _ i _ k, varphi _ (i _ 0 * cdots * i _ k)) element-of (F tensor-product Omega ^ p) * (U _ i _ 0 intersection cdots intersection U _ i _ k)

para.p: with the product topology and the suggestive computation rules. Each element of ⁢Ck(U,⊗FΩXp) thus has a unique representation of the form

Math.text: (sum _ (i _ 0 less cdots less i _ k))@(varphi _ (i _ 0 * cdots * i _ k) * U _ i _ 0) and cdots and U _ i _ k

para.p: that we will abbreviate as ∑′=|I|+k1⁢φIUI. We define a coboundary operator :δ→⁢Ck(U,⊗FΩXp)⁢C+k1(U,⊗FΩXp) by

Math.text: delta * ((sum ^ prime) _ (absolute-value@(I) = k + 1))@(varphi _ I * U _ I) assign ((sum ^ prime) _ (absolute-value@(I) = k + 1))@(varphi _ I * U _ I) and (sum _ j)@(U _ j) = ((sum ^ prime) _ (absolute-value@(I) = k + 1))@((sum _ j)@(varphi _ I)) restriction _ (U _ I intersection U _ j) U _ I and U _ j

para.p: which is continuous, and we get the following complex of Fréchet spaces

Math.text: 0 to C ^ 0 * open-interval@(U, F tensor-product (Omega _ X) ^ p) longrightarrow ^ delta C ^ 1 * open-interval@(U, F tensor-product (Omega _ X) ^ p) longrightarrow ^ delta cdots

para.p: The qth cohomology group of this complex is isomorphic to ⁢Hq(X,⊗FΩXp) and in fact, the standard topology on ⁢Hq(X,⊗FΩXp) is defined so that the isomorphism also is a homeomorphism.
Let B-np be the precosheaf (see, e.g., [12, Section 3]) defined by assigning to each open ⊂UX the space

Math.text: B ^ (n - p) * U assign H ^ n * open-interval@((B _ c) ^ (list@(n - p, bullet)) * open-interval@(U, F ^ *), [])

para.p: and for ⊂U′U the inclusion map :iU′U→⁢B-np(U′)⁢B-np(U) given by extension by 0. We let, for ≥k0, ⁢Cc-k(U,B-np) be the group of formal sums

Math.tex: \sum_{i_{0}\cdots i_{k}}[\psi_{i_{0}\cdots i_{k}}]_{\debar}U^{*}_{i_{0}}\wedge% \cdots\wedge U^{*}_{i_{k}},\quad\psi_{i_{0}\cdots i_{k}}\in\mathscr{B}_{c}^{n-% p,n}(U_{i_{0}}\cap\cdots\cap U_{i_{k}},F^{*}),
Math.text: list@((sum _ (i _ 0 * cdots * i _ k))@((delimited-[]@(psi _ (i _ 0 * cdots * i _ k))) _ [\debar] * (U ^ *) _ i _ 0) and cdots and (U ^ *) _ i _ k, psi _ (i _ 0 * cdots * i _ k)) element-of (B _ c) ^ (list@(n - p, n)) * open-interval@(U _ i _ 0 intersection cdots intersection U _ i _ k, F ^ *)

para.p: with the suggestive computation properties and only finitely many [ψ⁢i0⋯ik]\debar non-zero. We define the coboundary operator :δ*→⁢Cc-k(U,B-np)⁢Cc+-k1(U,B-np) by

Math.text: delta ^ * * ((sum ^ prime) _ (absolute-value@(I) = k + 1))@(delimited-[]@(psi _ I) * (U ^ *) _ I) assign (sum _ j)@(U _ j * lrcorner * ((sum ^ prime) _ (absolute-value@(I) = k + 1))@(delimited-[]@(psi _ I) * (U ^ *) _ I)) = ((sum ^ prime) _ (absolute-value@(I) = k + 1))@((sum _ j)@((i ^ (U _ I)) _ U _ (I set-minus set@(j)) * delimited-[]@(psi _ I) * U _ j * lrcorner * (U ^ *) _ I))

para.p: and we get the complex

Math.text: 0 leftarrow (C _ c) ^ 0 * open-interval@(U, B ^ (n - p)) longleftarrow ^ delta ^ * (C _ c) ^ (- 1) * open-interval@(U, B ^ (n - p)) longleftarrow ^ delta ^ * cdots

para.p: By Theorem 7.2, ⁢Cc-k(U,B-np) is the topological dual of ⁢Ck(U,⊗FΩXp) via the pairing

Math.text: C ^ k * open-interval@(U, F tensor-product (Omega _ X) ^ p) * (C _ c) ^ (- k) * open-interval@(U, B ^ (n - p)) to C

open-interval@(varphi, (delimited-[]@(psi)) _ [\debar]) = open-interval@(((sum ^ prime) _ (absolute-value@(I) = k + 1))@(varphi _ I * U _ I), ((sum ^ prime) _ (absolute-value@(I) = k + 1))@((delimited-[]@(psi _ I)) _ [\debar] * (U ^ *) _ I)) maps-to (integral _ X)@(varphi * lrcorner * psi) = ((sum ^ prime) _ (absolute-value@(I) = k + 1))@((integral _ X)@(varphi _ I)) and psi _ I

para.p: Moreover, if ∈φ⁢C-k1(U,⊗FΩXp) and ∈[ψ]⁢Cc-k(U,B-np), then

Math.text: (integral _ X)@(varphi * lrcorner * delta ^ * * psi) = (integral _ X)@(varphi * lrcorner * (sum _ j)@(U _ j * lrcorner * psi)) = (integral _ X)@((varphi and (sum _ j)@(U _ j)) * lrcorner * psi) = (integral _ X)@(delta * varphi * lrcorner * psi)

para.p: and so (7.4) is the dual complex of (7.3). It follows, see, e.g., [30, Lemme 2], that
is the topological dual of

Now, if ⁢Hq(X,⊗FΩXp) and ⁢H+q1(X,⊗FΩXp) are Hausdorff, then the closure signs in (7.6) and (7.7) are superfluous and so ⁢H-q(⁢C∙c(U,B-np),δ*) is the topological dual of ⁢Hq(X,⊗FΩXp) in this case, via the pairing induced by (7.5).
To understand ⁢H-q(⁢C∙c(U,B-np),δ*), consider the double complex

Math.text: K ^ (list@(- i, j)) assign (C _ c) ^ (- i) * open-interval@(U, (B _ c) ^ (list@(n - p, j)))

para.p: where Bc-np,j is the precosheaf ↦U⁢Bc-np,j(U) with inclusion maps given by extending by 0, the map →K-i,jK+-i1,j is δ*, and the map →K-i,jK-i,+j1 is \debar. For each ≥i0 the “row” K-i,∙ is, by Theorem 7.2, exact except for on the level n where the cohomology is ⁢C-ic(U,B-np). Since the BX-sheaves are fine it follows from, e.g., [31, Lemma 6.2] that, for each ≥j0, the “column” K∙,j is exact except for on the level 0 where the cohomology is ⁢Bc-np,j(X,F*). From, e.g., a spectral sequence argument it thus follows that

Math.text: H ^ (- q) * open-interval@((C ^ bullet) _ c * open-interval@(U, B ^ (n - p)), delta ^ *) similar-to-or-equals H ^ (n - q) * open-interval@((B _ c) ^ (list@(n - p, bullet)) * open-interval@(X, F ^ *), [])

para.p: Hence, we have a non-degenerate pairing (1.1) but we do not know that it is given by (1.2). To see this one makes the isomorphisms ≃⁢Hq(⁢Ap,∙(X,F),\debar)⁢Hq(X,⊗FΩXp) and (7.8) explicit; see the proof of [31, Theorem 1.3] for details.
